meaning_mnemonic: What <kanji>location</kanji> <kanji>suit</kanji>s a situation the best? That always depends on the <vocabulary>case</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>circumstance</vocabulary>. You can't know the suitability of the location until you have all the facts about the circumstances.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wait</kanji> so this word has something to do with waiting. Use the たせ as a hint. Someone "tossed" a ball off into a ditch, and then they had to find it. They made you wait for them to get the ball too, even though it's a cheap piece of crap. Feel upset about this. That'll help you remember that this means <vocabulary>to make someone wait</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to keep someone waiting</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>relationship</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is very short between you and your <vocabulary>comrade</vocabulary>s. You are <vocabulary>companion</vocabulary>s who have been through thick and thin together, so there's no distance between you.

仲間 is one of those very Japanese words that's hard to translate directly into English. It's a warm word that refers to people you share something with, like work, hobbies, goals, or even struggles. 仲間 aren't necessarily friends in the "get a coffee and chat" sense, but they're people with whom you've built a strong and special bond based on a shared experience or sense of purpose.

The <kanji>thing</kanji>s you <kanji>wear</kanji> are your <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary>. Oh, and Japanese clothes count too. We're talking <vocabulary>kimono</vocabulary>s. Way back when, these could just be called <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary> because it's all people really wore, but nowadays we know they're specific to the stereotypical kimono you think of when you think "Japan."
The things you <kanji>wear</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> your other clothes. That is your <vocabulary>underwear</vocabulary>. You do wear underwear, right?
<kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>wear</kanji> is a <vocabulary>swimsuit</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>bathing suit</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>swimwear</vocabulary>.

There is an <kanji>interval</kanji> (of time) that you need "to suit" (合う). To suit that interval, you need to be there before the time in question. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be in time for</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to make it on time</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be on time for</vocabulary>.

You've probably seen the words 知る and 合う by now. This is someone you "know" because you have "come together" before, but that's pretty much it. You don't really know them well, you just met them a couple times so you know who they are. This person is an <vocabulary>acquaintance</vocabulary>.

With <vocabulary>待ち</vocabulary> you know you're waiting, but what's a <vocabulary>ぼうけ</vocabulary>? Turns out it's the long version of ボケ which means idiot. Basically, in this case you're a waiting idiot. Why? because you were <vocabulary>stood up</vocabulary>.

This is a noun version of the kanji <kanji>feeling</kanji>. What is that? It's a <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary> as well.

感じ is a casual word that talks about a general feeling, <vocabulary>impression</vocabulary>, or vibe you get from something. You'll hear it everywhere — いい感じ (nice vibe), そんな感じ (something like that), or どんな感じ? (what's it like?).
<kanji>Everyone</kanji> (<kanji>formal name ender</kanji>). This is just a polite way to say <vocabulary>everyone</vocabulary> (and you want to be polite to everyone, because everyone > you).

This is a tricky word that doesn't really have a good translation. The best ways I've seen it done in terms of getting a meaning across are <vocabulary>please</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>. When you say this word you're kind of saying "please help me out and I'm relying on you and you're kind of awesome too." Anyways, <vocabulary>please</vocabulary> is a pretty good way to do it. So, when you see this word you'll notice it has the <kanji>request</kanji> kanji in it. You can guess you're requesting something. What is that thing? It's help (<vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>) and you're asking very nicely too (<vocabulary>please</vocabulary>).

meanings.meaning: If You Would Be So Kind

meaning_mnemonic:
One of the meanings of 本 is <kanji>main</kanji> (which is what we're using here). The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>public building</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main building</vocabulary>.

Sometimes 本館 can also mean <vocabulary>this building</vocabulary>, as in the one you're in. I guess whatever building you're in sort of becomes the main one to you, right?

You've seen the word 消す, I hope. This comes from that. You're extinguishing something with ゴム. ゴム is a word for either gummy or rubbery things. So, this is a gummy thing that extinguishes something. This is an <vocabulary>eraser</vocabulary> that extinguishes pencil markings.

Someone with <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is someone who has <vocabulary>evil intent</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>malice</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>ill will</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have too much 悪気.

You've hopefully seen how 登る means "to climb." So, if you're <kanji>climb</kanji>ing a <kanji>mountain</kanji> what is that? It's <vocabulary>mountain climbing</vocabulary>.

In case you're wondering what the difference is between this and 登山, they are essentially the same. The main difference is that 山登り is a little less formal, and is generally used as a standalone word, whereas 登山 can be used in compound words like 登山家 (mountaineer).

You know that 流行 means "trend", so "trend" <kanji>language</kanji> means a <vocabulary>popular phrase</vocabulary>. Yolo! It could also be a <vocabulary>catchphrase</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>popular word</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>buzzword</vocabulary>.
You know that 流行 refers to a "trend." So, a "trend" <kanji>song</kanji> is a <vocabulary>popular song</vocabulary>.
Something that's <kanji>outside</kanji> the <kanji>example</kanji> doesn't follow the rules. It's not what it's supposed to be (the example), it is the <vocabulary>exception</vocabulary>.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji> is just an <vocabulary>instance</vocabulary> of what you're describing. Just one <vocabulary>example</vocabulary>.

This has almost the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. Instead of just simply being "example," though, it's <vocabulary>for example</vocabulary>. It can also sometimes mean <vocabulary>supposing that</vocabulary> when talking about hypothetical scenarios. So, supposing that I start a sentence with this, I can be all like "例えば, I am using 例えば in a sentence."
<kanji>Example</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is a piece of writing that is an example for maybe a word or a kanji or something like that. This is an <vocabulary>example sentence</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>meet</kanji> for <kanji>cooperation</kanji>, you're coming together to help each other. One form of this is when people form <vocabulary>association</vocabulary>s. They're all cooperating and coming together to help each other and themselves.

<kanji>Cooperation</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is your level of <vocabulary>cooperation</vocabulary>. It's how much <vocabulary>collaboration</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assistance</vocabulary> you provide.

The kanji itself means <kanji>participate</kanji>, so you'd think this word would mean "to participate" but it's a little more complex than that. Think of it as "to participate" but where you have <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go</vocabulary> in order to do it. This is the humble way to say those things, so you're going to these places with your tail between your legs, just happy you can participate more than anything. By extension, this is also a humble way to say <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>, often used if you're visiting something sacred like a shrine or a tomb. 

Historically, this word arose as a humble way to indicate visiting a person of higher social status. In a weird twist, this word has come to also mean <vocabulary>to be defeated</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be at a loss</vocabulary>. Think of it as what can happen when you're trying to participate while in an inferior position to someone or something.

<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>circumference</kanji> is <vocabulary>one time around</vocabulary>, or in racetrack sports, <vocabulary>one lap</vocabulary>. How many times will you go around the moon? Just 一周?

The <kanji>circumference</kanji> that <kanji>surround</kanji>s you is your <vocabulary>surroundings</vocabulary>.

周囲 commonly refers to your surroundings, whether it's the physical environment around you or your social circles. It can also refer to the <vocabulary>perimeter</vocabulary> of something, like the <vocabulary>circumference</vocabulary> of a lake or an object, though this usage is more technical and less common in everyday conversation.

When you wrap around the entire <kanji> circumference</kanji> of the <kanji>year</kanji> you've come back around to the start of it. This is the <vocabulary>anniversary</vocabulary>.

This word is commonly used with numbers, like 10周年 (10th anniversary), or combined with other words, like 周年事業 (anniversary project).

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>surround</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to surround</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to enclose</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>surround</kanji>ing <kanji>energy</kanji> in the <kanji>atmosphere</kanji> is what makes up the <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary>. I love it when it takes three kanji to represent what one of the three kanji already represents.

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>hard</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>hard</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>tough</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>hard</kanji> <kanji>stubborn</kanji> person is very <vocabulary>stubborn</vocabulary> no matter how you look at them. Try to break through that hard stubbornness and all you'll find is more stubborn.

The <kanji>origin</kanji> of your <kanji>foundation</kanji> is where you have to work from when learning something new. For example, the 基本 portions of WaniKani are the earlier levels, especially the radicals. They are the <vocabulary>foundation</vocabulary> you need to learn your kanji and vocab later on.

The <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>season</kanji>s are <vocabulary>the four seasons</vocabulary>. For some reason many Japanese people think that Japan's the only place with four distinct seasons. Obviously they haven't been to half the places on their latitude around the world.
A <kanji>perfect</kanji> <kanji>finish</kanji> is when everything is at total <vocabulary>completion</vocabulary>. Nothing is left over and all is done.

When something is <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>perfect</kanji> it is <vocabulary>complete</vocabulary>. Not only that, but it's <vocabulary>perfect</vocabulary> (because it's ALL perfect, not just partially so).
When something has <kanji>become</kanji> <kanji>perfect</kanji> it has reached <vocabulary>completion</vocabulary>.
What your <kanji>thought</kanji>s <kanji>request</kanji> inside your head, nonstop like a crazy person, are your <vocabulary>heart's desire</vocabulary>s.

You have <kanji>remainder</kanji> <kanji>thoughts</kanji> when your hear about something <vocabulary>unfortunate</vocabulary>. That's <vocabulary>too bad</vocabulary>, you think, I wish it could have been different. Those remainder thoughts are a kind of regret, right? That's why this can mean <vocabulary>regrettable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>disappointing</vocabulary> too.
A <kanji>person</kanji>'s <kanji>nature</kanji> is just <vocabulary>human nature</vocabulary>! Everyone has their own human <vocabulary>instinct</vocabulary>s.
Someone who's of the <kanji>woman</kanji> <kanji>gender</kanji> is probably going to be <vocabulary>female</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>gender</kanji> <kanji>sick</kanji>ness is one you catch from *ahem* doing things with those of another or the same gender. You only catch these sicknesses this way, meaning they're <vocabulary>sexually transmitted disease</vocabulary>s (save yourself some typing and just answer with <vocabulary>STD</vocabulary>).

A <kanji>man</kanji>'s <kanji>gender</kanji> is known as "<vocabulary>male</vocabulary>."

Note that this can only refer to a human's gender; you're going to learn the word you use for animals, plants, etc. later on!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fold</kanji> or <kanji>break</kanji>, so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to fold something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to break something</vocabulary>

When there's nothing but <kanji>fold</kanji>s and <kanji>angle</kanji>s, you have quite a mess. This word means <vocabulary>with trouble</vocabulary> because you certainly aren't traversing along a nice, flat piece of space-time, are you? Nah, it's all angled and folded.

折角 is one of those tricky Japanese words that doesn’t have one neat translation in English. The nuance is that something has come about with trouble, either through someone’s efforts, or a stroke of luck. It often implies regret, and is used in situations where you want to express that <vocabulary>valuable</vocabulary> opportunities, advice, or hard work were in vain for some reason. It’s also used to underline a <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary> chance that shouldn’t be missed.
When your <kanji>bone</kanji> <kanji>break</kanji>s, you end up with, well, a <vocabulary>broken bone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fracture</vocabulary>.
There is <kanji>fault</kanji> in your <kanji>hope</kanji>. It breaks, and everything falls apart. You feel massive <vocabulary>disappointment</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>despair</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>hope</kanji> is really a <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary> that you have inside of you (though it can still be a <vocabulary>hope</vocabulary> too).

If you have a <kanji>hope</kanji> and you turn it into a verb, you'd think it would be "to hope." But what is really behind a hope? It's a desire or wish, right? That's why this word means <vocabulary>to wish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to desire</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>hope</kanji> you <kanji>request</kanji> is your <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself hoping and requesting some higher power for something you really want. What is this? It's your <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Wood</kanji> that is <kanji>lumber</kanji> is <vocabulary>lumber</vocabulary> <vocabulary>wood</vocabulary>.

Technically speaking, 木材 is used more for lumber or wood that hasn't been processed yet — less like planks, more like freshly cut lumber still lying on the forest floor. But it's not a hard rule or anything, so don't worry too much about the nuances.

You have to pay a <kanji>fee</kanji> for the <kanji>material</kanji> you use to make food. Those are the <vocabulary>ingredients</vocabulary> you're paying for! Imagine making a list of all of the materials you need to make a stew, then making sure you have enough to pay the fees, so you'll have all the ingredients you need to make it.

<kanji>Lumber</kanji> <kanji>tree</kanji>s are what you use to make <vocabulary>lumber</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>timber</vocabulary>.

材木 is typically for lumber or timber that's been processed — the stuff that's cut into planks and ready to use in your next DIY project, for example.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>promise</kanji> <kanji>bundle</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>promise</vocabulary> no matter how many you have wrapped up there. One promise is just another promise which is just another promise.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>pine</kanji> <kanji>leaves</kanji> are not really leaves, they're more like needles, thus making this word <vocabulary>pine needle</vocabulary>.

松葉 is commonly used in compounds, such as 松葉ガニ (snow crab) or 松葉づえ (crutches).

Your <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>status</kanji> refers to what kind of person you are deep-down. In other words, it's your <vocabulary>character</vocabulary>. Are you a person of character? Do you have a strong moral character?!

人格 is about the kind of person you are at your core. It's not about surface-level traits like being shy, cheerful, or forgetful, but about the deeper qualities that define you as a human being. In philosophical or scientific contexts, it can also refer to a person's <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary> as a technical concept, including intelligence and behavioral patterns.

The <kanji>status</kanji> <kanji>joins</kanji> together. Think of this like a bunch of status messages on Facebook, all coming together at the same time. A big government test has just finished. Everyone's status' are joining on Facebook together to say they passed, showing <vocabulary>to pass a test</vocabulary>.

Remember how 性 can also mean <kanji>nature</kanji>? Well, the <kanji>status</kanji> of your nature is your <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary>. What kind of personality do you have? Cheerful? Kind? Maybe you should take one of those online personality tests to find out.

You <kanji>like</kanji> the <kanji>status</kanji> of what's in front of you. It has an excellent <vocabulary>shape</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>form</vocabulary> to it. Imagine something that would be pleasing to you in terms of its shape.
The <kanji>status</kanji> of your <kanji>bones</kanji> (aka how they're all arranged and put together) equals your <vocabulary>skeleton</vocabulary>. That bone status is lookin' good on you!
This has the same meaning as the kanji. The little り thrown on there is just a little <vocabulary>remainder</vocabulary> sticking off the end of the kanji. No need to pay attention to that.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>remainder</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is "to remainder." Let's make that sound better: <vocabulary>to remain behind</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of time that you work at the ol' <kanji>business</kanji> is extra time that you're working (above the normal work hours). This is <vocabulary>overtime</vocabulary>!

There is a <kanji>reason</kanji> for this <kanji>fee</kanji> that you have to pay to get in here. We are <vocabulary>cooking</vocabulary> <vocabulary>cuisine</vocabulary> for you to eat while you're watching the show. If we weren't cooking a <vocabulary>dish</vocabulary> for you, we probably wouldn't charge you this fee!

This is a strange word, I'm afraid. You'll have to bear with it. This, when added onto a word, is like adding an <vocabulary>-al</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>-like</vocabulary> to the end of it—or when something is <vocabulary>typical of</vocabulary> something else. For example, add it onto 日本 (Japan) and you have "Japanese-like", or "typically Japanese". It's a weird sort of modifying word that really depends on each situation it's in. For now, just know this word means these things. We'll start applying it to various words in the future, slowly but surely.

Things that are <kanji>target</kanji>ed as <vocabulary>Japanese</vocabulary> are more than just Japanese, they are <vocabulary>very Japanese</vocabulary>. This word may be hard to understand at first, but there are many things the Japanese consider to be Japanese-only. These theories range from reasonable to ridiculous, but either way, you'll see them described as 日本的.

When your <kanji>eye</kanji> is on the <kanji>target</kanji> you know your <vocabulary>purpose</vocabulary>. You also have your eye on the <vocabulary>goal</vocabulary> (that's the target, after all!).
A <kanji>beforehand</kanji> <kanji>promise</kanji> is a promise you've made beforehand. This is a <vocabulary>reservation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>appointment</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right?

The kanji means <kanji>promise</kanji>, but the meaning of this word is <vocabulary>about</vocabulary>, which is a little different. Just think about promises. When you promise something you really need to follow through... but only about as much as you need to for the other person to be happy. Someone asks for a puppy for Christmas, and you get them a stuffed animal puppy. It's <vocabulary>approximately</vocabulary> the promise you made. Close enough. *wink*
A person who has great <kanji>talent</kanji> and <kanji>ability</kanji> has quite the <vocabulary>talent</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>ability</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is what you can do. This is your <vocabulary>ability</vocabulary>. It is also your <vocabulary>capability</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>art</kanji> <kanji>ability</kanji> <kanji>world</kanji> is the world of <vocabulary>show business</vocabulary>, or in other words, the <vocabulary>entertainment industry</vocabulary>. To get into show business, you need abilities in the arts, after all.

What is the greatest <kanji>art</kanji> a <kanji>person</kanji> can possess? It’s got to be the art of making people laugh. That’s why this means <vocabulary>comedian</vocabulary>, though it can also mean a <vocabulary>performer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>entertainer</vocabulary> more generally.
The <kanji>art</kanji>s are performed by <kanji>someone</kanji>. Who is that someone? Well, think about the reading for this kanji. Do you recognize the word? It's <vocabulary>geisha</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Hey. <kanji>Drop</kanji> yourself down and <kanji>arrive</kanji> back to me. You're going nuts over there. Lower down. Come back. Arrive. You need to do these things <vocabulary>to calm down</vocabulary>.
You know how 消化 is "digestion"? Well, The verb form of that is this word, which is <vocabulary>to digest</vocabulary>.

You've seen that 消す is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary> on its own. How can you differentiate this from 消す? Well, える allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin <reading>air</reading> (える). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.
The 気持ち (feeling) is <kanji>bad</kanji>. So, you can imagine how you feel isn't good, it's a <vocabulary>bad feeling</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>feeling terrible</vocabulary>, in fact.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stream</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>to stream</vocabulary> (though it's also <vocabulary>to flow</vocabulary>, a very similar word). You can differentiate this from 流す because with 流す you flush something down the toilet, which causes it to overflow so you <reading>sue</reading> (す) the toilet maker. With 流れる you find a <reading>rare</reading> (れる) jewel trying to flow down the river. You grab it, and see it's a rare diamond!

You've seen 動く hopefully, and know it means <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>. This is similar to that, but now you're moving something else. You know this because as you go <vocabulary>to move something</vocabulary> the thing you're moving starts to <reading>cuss</reading> (かす) you out because it's angry.

Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: 着る (to wear), 着く (to arrive), and now 着ける (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to 着る, right? In this case, this word is like 付ける, which means "to attach." It's used for things you "attach" to your body to wear, like accessories, or a face mask. That's why this is <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary>. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.
You've seen 勉強 (study) by now, right? Well, this is the verb version of that. This is <vocabulary>to study</vocabulary>.

You've hopefully seen 旅行 by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's <vocabulary>to travel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take a trip</vocabulary>. These are fun to do. You should do them!

You've seen 起きる which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are waking someone else up, which makes the meaning of this word <vocabulary>to wake someone up</vocabulary>. How do you differentiate between this and 起きる? Because of the す on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and <reading>sue</reading> (す) you, making you wish you never woke them up.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to cause something</vocabulary>. I guess if you wake someone up and they're not a morning person, you could cause something... like trouble.
You've seen that 旅行 is "trip." So who is <kanji>someone</kanji> who goes on trips? That is a <vocabulary>tourist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>traveler</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> produces nothing but <vocabulary>bad-mouthing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>trash-talk</vocabulary>.

悪口 often targets someone's character, appearance, or abilities, with the intention of hurting them or damaging their reputation, sometimes to their face, but often behind their back. It gives rise to unfavorable information that can spread through gossip.
A <kanji>good</kanji> <kanji>like</kanji> is something you like really good, if that makes any sense. This thing is a <vocabulary>good</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>favorable</vocabulary> thing.
When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> something with <kanji>reason</kanji> you're arranging it. That's why this is <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary>.
Something that can <kanji>move</kanji> by its <kanji>self</kanji> is something that's <vocabulary>automatic</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>business</kanji> of you <kanji>graduating</kanji> is your <vocabulary>graduation</vocabulary>. If you think about it, it's kind of a big business, getting you graduated from expensive schools. The graduation business focuses on graduations, and getting you there (hint: this business is a school, probably).

Both your <kanji>hope</kanji>s and <kanji>wish</kanji>es are held within this vocab word. So, what is the meaning of this word? It is both <vocabulary>hope</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary>. Either will work.

When you have <kanji>gentle</kanji> <kanji>cooperation</kanji> nobody has their way. You're very gently coming towards the middle, coming to a <vocabulary>compromise</vocabulary>. (Whether you like it or not.)

You've hopefully seen 消化 by now and know that it means "digestion." If you know that, then you can see that the "digestion" is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good</kanji>. When your digestion is not good, what do you have? <vocabulary>Indigestion</vocabulary>. Excuse me, I have to run to the restroom...
Hopefully you know the word 期待 by now (expectation). This is the verb version, which makes it <vocabulary>to expect</vocabulary>.

You know that 回転 is "rotation" and you probably know what すし is (gets rendaku'd in this word to ずし). So, what is "rotation sushi?" It's <vocabulary>rotating sushi</vocabulary>, also known as <vocabulary>conveyor belt sushi</vocabulary>. Look it up if you don't know what it is.
You know that 回転 means "rotation" or "revolution." So, what happens when you make it into a verb? It becomes <vocabulary>to rotate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to revolve</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>attempt</kanji> to <kanji>join</kanji> together isn't just any get together. Imagine two people boxing. They attempt to knock each other out when they join together. That's why this word is <vocabulary>game</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>match</vocabulary>. Did you watch the 試合 today? No! Don't tell me what happened, I recorded it on the VHS.
理解 is "understanding," so the verb version would be...? How about <vocabulary>to understand</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to comprehend</vocabulary>? Well, do you?
A <kanji>closed</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is when a store's status is <vocabulary>store closed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>closed store</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Open</kanji>ed and <kanji>closed</kanji> things are <vocabulary>opening and closing</vocabulary>.

開閉 is a relatively formal word to refer to the action of opening and closing physical objects such as doors, shutters, or valves. You often see it in instruction manuals or product descriptions.
<kanji>I</kanji> with a ら on it makes it plural. It's less formal than 俺たち (if you've seen that word yet), but has the same meaning. It's <vocabulary>we</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>well</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>. It's the door that goes into the well hole, making it a well.

You know that the alternative kanji meaning for 合 is <kanji>join</kanji>, which is what we're using here. The verb form of join is <vocabulary>to join together</vocabulary>, and it can also mean <vocabulary>to unify</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to match</vocabulary>.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Much Appreciated For Your Hard Work

meaning_mnemonic: You are a 疲れ (tired) 様 (honorific that kind of refers to whoever's being mentioned). You say this to people when they've done good work — at the end of a workday or after a hard practice, for example. I guess the idea is that if they're tired, they've done some good work. Tell your coworkers お疲れ様でした when they leave for the day, or just use お疲れ in more casual situations with friends!

meanings.meaning: Thank You For Your Hard Work

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

性 is a somewhat formal word to talk about <vocabulary>gender</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>sex</vocabulary>, including sexual desire or activity. It's also a common suffix to describe the <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary> of something. 安全性 refers to how safe something is by nature, for example, and ウィルス性 describes something virus-caused, like viral pneumonia.
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>move</kanji>. So it means <vocabulary>movement</vocabulary>.
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>circumference</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>circumference</vocabulary> too.
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>deep</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>depth</vocabulary>.

If you follow the <kanji>circumference</kanji> of a <kanji>period of time</kanji>, you end up back at the beginning and it makes a full <vocabulary>cycle</vocabulary>. Events in history always repeat, right?

If you have <kanji>reason</kanji> in your <kanji>nature</kanji>, you have <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>sense</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intellect</vocabulary>.

This is "reason" as in logical thinking.
The place you <kanji>wait</kanji> to <kanji>join</kanji> other people is a <vocabulary>waiting room</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>meeting place</vocabulary>.

Remember how 言葉 means "language?" Well, the way you "attach" (付き) language to things is your <vocabulary>diction</vocabulary>. Everyone has their own 言葉つき when they speak. How would you describe your 言葉つき?

言葉つき refers to the characteristics of <vocabulary>how one speaks</vocabulary>, including the words they choose, how they say them, and their overall speaking style.

You have to find the right <kanji>tool</kanji> to <kanji>suit</kanji> your <vocabulary>condition</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>state</vocabulary>. If you have a <vocabulary>health</vocabulary> condition, the tool is a pill, or exercise, or real life friends. But it always depends on the condition you're in.

You wouldn't put your <kanji>idea</kanji> in a <kanji>diagram</kanji> <kanji>~like</kanji> format if it wasn't <vocabulary>intentional</vocabulary>. Doing that takes a lot of work. So you can only make diagram like things <vocabulary>on purpose</vocabulary>!

Something that is <kanji>near</kanji> <kanji>period</kanji> <kanji>like</kanji> is very <vocabulary>contemporary</vocabulary>. But if it looks like it's from a period not near the one you're in... throw it away! It isn't <vocabulary>modern</vocabulary> enough to touch your hands!
A person whose <kanji>idea</kanji>s are <kanji>ground</kanji>ed in <kanji>evil</kanji> is a <vocabulary>malicious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>mean</vocabulary> <vocabulary>jerk</vocabulary>!
A <kanji>diagram</kanji> everyone <kanji>join</kanji>s together to see is a <vocabulary>signal</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>sign</vocabulary>.

Remember how 文化 means "culture?" Well add <kanji>festival</kanji> to it and you end up with a <vocabulary>culture festival</vocabulary>! These happen all the time at Japanese schools, so sometimes they're called <vocabulary>school festival</vocabulary>s too.

The <kanji>abilities</kanji> you <kanji>origin</kanji>ally start out with are <vocabulary>instinct</vocabulary>s. Animals have lots of them because they aren't very good at learning. They have to start out knowing them from the start.

Remember how 運動 means "exercise?" When you <kanji>meet</kanji> with a bunch of other people to exercise it's called <vocabulary>Sports Day</vocabulary>! This is a day at schools in Japan where everybody does physical stuff together! It's fun and also very tiring!

What do you use to get a <kanji>person</kanji> to <kanji>participate</kanji> in something? A <vocabulary>carrot</vocabulary>, of course. You've heard of "the carrot and the stick," right? So next time you want a person to participate, offer them a carrot.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends in an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 温 means <kanji>warm</kanji>. So the verb 温まる means <vocabulary>to warm up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get warm</vocabulary>. 

温まる is intransitive, so no direct object needed. Your cat warms up in the sunlight, for example. No direct object, right? A hint for this is that 温まる ends with okurigana that rhyme with ある, and those kinds of verbs tend to be intransitive!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
What’s another word for a <kanji>wolf</kanji> <kanji>man</kanji>? A <vocabulary>werewolf</vocabulary>, obviously.

You write the word <kanji>go</kanji> on a <vocabulary>line of text</vocabulary>. See the word "go" on that <vocabulary>line</vocabulary>, and think about where you're going.

This word can also be used for <vocabulary>row</vocabulary>s (horizontal lines in Excel and other spreadsheets).

This word is pretty straightforward. You have <kanji>fur</kanji> and <kanji>skin</kanji>, making a word meaning <vocabulary>fur</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pelt</vocabulary>, like the kind that can be used to make garments.
When it's <kanji>bright</kanji> around, things become more <vocabulary>obvious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>clear</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>evident</vocabulary>.
Older <kanji>generation</kanji>s mostly <kanji>talk</kanji> about one thing: <vocabulary>care</vocabulary>. Everybody wants to receive care once they're older, don't they?
